newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot resids mostly lose ground with crude.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot resids mostly lose ground with crude.

text.p: U.S. spot residual fuel prices mostly lost ground Wednesday in sluggish trade, with a sharp slide in crude and forecasts for mild East Coast weather driving buyers to the sidelines, industry sources said.

"The general tone seems to be changing for lower levels. I don't see it totally collapsing, but I think we're in for a little correction," said one cash trader, noting sharp losses in crude left buyers reluctant to commit.
In New York Harbor, physical one percent was off slightly to about $21.25 a barrel, with November paper more than 30 cents lower at $21.10-30 on weaker crude, traders said.
NYH December one percent paper also lost about 30 cents to $21.20-40.
Traders said prospects for better high sulphur supplies and softer bunkers were pressuring HSFO prices. NYH 2.2 percent was down slightly to $20.50-75.
At the U.S. Gulf, one percent was a quarter lower at $19.75, while three percent was down by 25-50 cents to $19.25-50.
No NYH or USG deals were reported.

New York City gate gas prices firmed another five cents Wednesday to the high-$2.90s/mmBtu versus NYH one percent resid at a $3.37/mmBtu equivalent. November New York gas was still quoted at about NYMEX plus 65 cents, or in the $3.20/mmBtu area versus a resid paper equivalent of $3.37.
